title: As a human, we have the abilities to make a change. Is this sentence wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: Alas yes, it’s wrong in multiple ways. “As a human, we” - the plurality of the first clause and the second must agree. Best fit would be “As humans, we”; you could say “As a human, you” or “As a human, I”, but that would be more dependant on context. “have the abilities” - not completely wrong, but since you’re talking about a single characteristic that humans possess, it’d be more normal to put this in the singular: “have the ability”. “make a change” - our ability isn’t limited to making one change only. “make changes” would be more appropriate; “make change” could also be used (meaning that we can make “change” as an abstract concept as opposed to “changes” as individual concrete things) but it’s less common. So: “As humans, we have the ability to make changes.”

Yes, you’re mixing up singulars and plurals. “As a human (singular), I/you/he/she (singular) have/has the ability to make a change (making a change is the only ability you mentioned, so ability would be singular).” Or, if you meant to speak of multiple people: “As humans (plural), we/you/they (plural) have the ability to make a change (still only talking about one ability, so ‘ability’ remains singular).”
Yes, the sentence is wrong. Because “a human” is singular and “we have” is plural. The correct construction is….. “Being human, we have the abilities to make changes.”
Yes, change is one of the very few constants. whether we want to or not and whether it is a good thing or not, we're constantly changing the world
